information_requirement: Is an adversary hiding malicious applications on our mobile devices by suppressing their icons? (TA0030 - Defense Evasion)

evidence.description: An application is found in the device's complete installation inventory but does not have a corresponding icon in the main application launcher. This suggests the app's launcher activity has been programmatically disabled to hide its presence from the user.
evidence.action: On a recurring basis (e.g., daily), use the MDM/EDR platform to pull two lists from all managed devices: 1) a complete list of all installed application packages (e.g., from PackageManager). 2) a list of all applications with a registered launcher activity. Use a script to perform a differential analysis between the two lists. Any application present in the first list but absent from the second is a high-confidence indicator of a hidden app. Prioritize alerts for non-system applications that also possess high-risk permissions.

evidence.description: On a device running Android 10 or newer, a user taps an application icon and is redirected to the app's detail page in the system settings instead of the application opening. This is evidence of a 'synthesized activity', a placeholder icon created by the OS for an app that has attempted to hide its primary icon.
evidence.action: Configure MDM/EDR solutions to monitor for a sequence of process events: a user tap within the launcher application followed immediately by the launch of the system settings activity (`com.android.settings`). Correlate this event sequence with the application that was the target of the tap. Establish a baseline for legitimate apps that might exhibit this behavior (if any). Use a statistical approach to flag applications that cause this redirection event across multiple devices at a rate that is a significant deviation from the norm. Supplement this automated detection with a user awareness campaign instructing users on how to identify and report this specific behavior.

evidence.description: Static analysis of an application package (APK) reveals programmatic calls to disable its own main launcher activity component, a method used to hide the application icon post-installation.
evidence.nai: Organizational application stores and application vetting sandboxes
evidence.action: Integrate an application vetting sandbox into the mobile application deployment lifecycle. For any new or updated application, automatically scan its `AndroidManifest.xml` to ensure it has a `LAUNCHER` intent. Furthermore, perform static code analysis to search for the use of the `PackageManager.setComponentEnabledSetting()` function paired with the `COMPONENT_ENABLED_STATE_DISABLED` flag targeting its own launcher activity. An application using this combination without a clear and legitimate purpose (e.g., a setup wizard that disables itself after first run) should be flagged for manual review before being approved for deployment.
